educational_objective: Recognize the ash-leaf spot and its association with tuberous sclerosis complex.
question_text: A 19-year-old woman with epilepsy and learning disabilities is evaluated for the skin findings shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The elliptical hypopigmented macule in this image is recognized as the ash-leaf spot associated with tuberous sclerosis (Option D), a congenital neurocutaneous syndrome. Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a genetic disorder with mutations in the tumor-suppressing genes TSC1 or TSC2 and resulting tumors in many organs, primarily the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. Most patients have cutaneous findings, including hypopigmented macules (ash-leaf spots), angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and fibrous forehead plaques. Epilepsy is present in most patients with tuberous sclerosis, and cognitive deficits, learning disabilities, and behavioral problems are also common.
